section_purpose: To describe the datasets prepared for experimental evaluation, including small-scale symmetric circuits, medium-size CNF formulas, and large random circuits, detailing their construction and characteristics.
key_points: Three datasets are prepared: small-scale symmetric AIGs, medium-size CNF formulas (SR(n) problems), and large random AIGs (V(n) problems).
The small-scale dataset is manually constructed with 10 circuits having symmetric inputs but asymmetric solutions, designed to test existing methods like NeuroSAT and DG-DAGRNN.
Medium-size datasets (SR(n)) are generated similarly to prior work and converted to circuit form using Shannon's Decomposition.
Large-scale datasets (V(n)) are generated using the AIGEN tool, extracting combinational circuits from sequential ones, and are complex with over 1K logic gates for V(10) problems.

datasets: Small-scale symmetric AIG: 10 manually constructed circuits, no more than 3 inputs, symmetric input nodes with distinct assignments.
Medium-size CNF formulas: SR(n) problems generated as per [Selsam et al., 2018], n is number of variables, converted using Shannon's Decomposition.

Large random AIGs: V(n) problems generated with AIGEN tool [Jacobs and Sakr, 2021], n is number of inputs, average >1K logic gates for V(10), CNF formulas have >1K variables via Tseitin transformation.

dependencies: Prior work by Selsam et al. (2018) for SR(n) problem generation.
Shannon's Decomposition method from Amizadeh et al. (2018).
AIGEN tool by Jacobs and Sakr (2021) for generating random circuits.
Background on SAT problems and GNN-based solving from section 2.
reproducibility_notes: Manual construction details for small-scale symmetric circuits with asymmetric solutions.
Generation procedure for SR(n) problems following prior work specifications.
Use of AIGEN tool to create sequential circuits and extraction of combinational logic.
Application of Shannon's Decomposition for CNF to circuit conversion and Tseitin transformation for circuit to CNF conversion.
